FINANCIAL YEAR 1ST JANUARY,

1969, TO 31ST MARCH, 1970



    Order read for consideration in Committee of Supply [Allotted Day].

[Mr Speaker in the Chair]



    The Chairman: Development Estimates of Singapore for the financial year 1st January, 1969, to 31st March, 1970, contained in Paper Cmd. 28 of 1968. For the convenience of hon. Members, I intend taking the total for each head of expenditure as it appears in the last column of the Summary of Estimated Expenditure on pages 5 and 6 of the Paper.

Column: 698



    Before we get on to that, I may perhaps remind Members that we are on the Development Estimates and debate on the policy or day-to-day running of the Ministries of various heads of expenditure that appear in the Estimates will not be permitted.

    Head 11 -

    Mr Teong Eng Siong (Sembawang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the total sum to be allocated for Head 11 be reduced by $100.

    The sum allocated for this Head is $341,000 for the period 1969-70. The

Column: 699

main purpose of this sum is to purchase furniture and equipment and also for works and buildings. We all know that the National Museum is very important because it provides educative information to our people, but in the past it has been neglected. Now that the Museum is under the Ministry of Science and Technology, I hope that it will be properly developed, and since the Minister is a specialist in biology, he will be able to get exhibits of animals and insects from all over the world to replenish the present stock in the Museum. In this way, our student population will be able to widen their knowledge and also to learn more about past and present dev elopments, especially on the history of natural science.

    I would like to ask the Minister two questions. The captions of the exhibits in the Museum are in English and the scientific names are also in English. Will the Minister consider whether the captions can be put in the four official languages for the benefit of the people? Secondly, what types of furniture and equipment will be purchased?

    The Minister for Science and Technology (Dr Toh Chin Chye): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Sembawang has a good idea. I shall bring it to the attention of my officials and ensure that the exhibits are explained in the four official languages - English, Chinese, Malay and Tamil.

    May I inform Members of the House how the money which has been allocated for the National Museum will be spent? A sum of $185,000 will be spent on works and buildings. This involves the construction of a bridge to link up the eastern side of the front and rear building, the construction of an external wall to link up the northern side of the front and rear building, the demolition of garages and construction of two internal court yard s.

    The sum of $156,000 is allocated for the purchase of furniture and equipment. This includes electric light fittings for show cases, moveable show cases for the public galleries, shelves for reference

Column: 700

collections and stores, a deep-freeze unit for storage of animals and carcasses, a freeze drier, an air-condition unit and two microscopes.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong(In Mandarin): Sir, in view of the Minister's explanation, I beg leave to withdraw the amendment.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    The sum of $341,000 for Head 11 ordered to stand part of the Development Estimates.

Column: 700



    Head 21 -

    Mr Ho Kah Leong (Jurong)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 21 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 101.

    This subhead relates to "Loan to Jurong Town Corporation". Can the Minister say in what way will the allocated sum of $30 million be used to develop the Jurong Town Corporation in order to supplement the various amenities and facilities?

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Sir, the Jurong Town Corporation asked for a loan of $56 million to finance various development projects next year. The Ministry of Finance was able to agree to only $30 million and this sum will be spent as follows: development of land, that is to say, land reclamation, earthworks, construction of roads, sewers, electrical sub-stations and so on $10.4 million is at Jurong and $2.8 million in the other estates outside Jurong. The second item is on factory buildings. A sum of $3.5 million is to be spent on factory buildings in Jurong for sale or lease to private enterprise, and $6.5 million will be spent on constructing factory buildings in other industrial estates. The third item is on improvement to facilities in the Jurong wharves. This will entail an expenditure of $2 million. The fourth item is housing at Jurong which is expected to cost $2½ million. The fifth item is a small one in which $200,000 will be spent on the

Column: 701

industrial water scheme at Jurong. A sum of $1.6 million has been allotted for development of social amenities of which $1.1 million is earmarked for the development of Jurong Park.

    There are other small items such as organisation facilities - Town Hall -$200,000. I am not quite clear what this really means. I think the Jurong Town Corporation has an ambitious plan to construct a very noble town hall, and maybe this $200,000 will go into the preliminary studies and designs. Then there is an item of $100,000 against common amenities and $200,000 for research and investigations.

    Mr Ho Kah Leong(In Mandarin): Sir, I beg leave to withdraw the amendment.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    Mr Ng Yeow Chong (Mountbatten): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 21 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 103*.
* The same amendment also stood in the name of Mr Ch'ng Jit Koon.


    The point I wish to raise under this subhead concerns the prevention and extinguishment of fire in Housing Board flats. At the present moment, no fire. fighting equipment is installed in Housing Board flats.

    Sir, you are aware that all new buildings in our Republic are subject to regulations made under the Local Government Integration Ordinance, 1963. May I quote section 147 of the Local Government Buildings Regulations, 1966, which reads:

    'Every new building, except residential buildings and business premises under four storeys in height and not exceeding two thousand square feet in area at first floor level, shall be provided with water supply independent of the domestic supply conveyed in pipes of steel or cast iron and with hydrants and pumps and extinguishers for the prevention and extinguishment of fire to the' satisfaction of the Chief Building Surveyor.'

    Sir, this being the case, may I therefore ask the Minister to clarify whether

Column: 702

there is an oversight on the part of the Housing and Development Board to provide fire-fighting equipment in flats or blocks of flats in the interests of the tenants? Further, I wish to know whether sufficient fire hydrants are installed in all housing estates belonging to the Housing and Development Board.

    Mr Ch'ng Jit Koon (Tiong Bahru): Sir, I am not moving.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Law and National Development (National Development Division) (Mr Ho Cheng Choon): Mr Speaker, Sir, it is an acceptable practice all over the world to grant exemption from certain requirements of the building bylaws to low-cost housing in order to bring down the cost. Similarly, the Housing and Development Board has obtained exemption from the Chief Building Surveyor for the provision of fire-fighting equipment, among others, in our low-cost housing so that the cost of these housing flats could be reduced to an acceptable level. There is provision under section 169 of the Local Government Buildings Regulations, 1966, for giving such an exemption.

    During the last eight years, not a single case of fire has occurred in any of the Housing Board flats, which means that they are very safe and sound.

2.45 p.m.

    Small fires such as those caused by the tipping over of kerosene stoves have never been able to spread to the next flats due to the sound design and non- inflammable materials used in these multi-storey buildings. Moreover, adequate hydrants have been provided in all the housing estates for use by the Fire Brigade in the event of an emergency. The Chief Building Surveyor considered these facts and agreed that exemption from the building by-laws for the provision of fire-fighting equipment could be granted to housing estates. Fire-fighting equipment is very expensive and it is often tampered with or stolen

Column: 703

when it is stored in the Housing Board estates. In fact, the Housing Board did install fire-fighting equipment in the flats built under the First Five-Year Plan but, unfortunately, most of it has either been stolen immediately after installation or tampered with by the residents. In view of this, it serves no useful purpose to spend a large sum of money to install fire-fighting equipment in the Housing Board estates.

    Mr Ng Yeow Chong: The Parliamentary Secretary has said that no fire 'can spread in Housing Board flats. In the last three years, two fires have broken out in Housing Board flats in the Old Kallang Airport Estate. More recently, a fire in the Bukit Ho Swee area almost threatened an adjacent block 'of flats in the Bukit Ho Swee Estate.

    In spite of this, I am satisfied that sufficient hydrants have been installed in the housing estates. Therefore, I beg leave to withdraw.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the total sum to be allocated for Head 21 be reduced by $100.

    Sir, the sum of $131,480,900 under this head is provided for various purposes, such as "Loan to Development Bank of Singapore - $30 million", "Loan to Jurong Town Corporation -$30 million", "Loan to Public Utilities Board - $20 million", "Loan to Housing and Development Board -$50 million", etc. These allocations are very important for our economic development and prosperity. But I would like to know the purposes of the other subheads for which various sums of money have been allocated. Can I have more details of the item "Seletar Dam - Anti-Pollution Measures - $463,200", and of the remaining subheads 401, 402, 501 and 601?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: In order to ensure high standards of purity of water when it flows into the Seletar Dam, certain measures have to be taken in the catchment area to the reservoir. The

Column: 704

Member for Sembawang will know that unlike the central catchment area feeding the two reservoirs - MacRitchie and Peirce - the Seletar Reservoir catchment area is populated mainly by farmers. It is not feasible or necessary to resettle these farmers. But certain safeguards have to be carried out, namely, the construction of latrines, cess-pits, pigsties, and so on. This involves a total cost of $1.8 million, part of which is paid by the Government and part by the farmers. The scheme is being implemented in stages. A sum of $454,000 has been spent this year and the balance will be spent next year. The project is expected to be completed by the middle of next year when the Seletar Reservoir will provide us with a very useful increase in water storage capacity.

    Subhead 401 concerns "P.A.B.X. Equipment for Fullerton Building". I am unable to get details of the price break-down from the Singapore Telephone Board. The equipment is manufactured in Sweden and its purchase price was quoted by the Telephone Board as $126,547. Before its installation in November last year, the Telephone Board conducted a survey of telephone requirements of all the departments in Fullerton Building with the exception of the Postal Department, the Telecommunications Department and the Economic Development Board. The engineers recommended that an expandable P.A.B.X, unit for 50 exchange lines and 500 extensions equipped initially with 40 exchange lines and 300 extensions be installed. The equipment is at present rented from the Telephone Board at a cost of $23,542 per annum. It is expected to last for 25 to 30 years and calculations show that in the long run it is more economical to purchase the equipment outright as the capital cost will be recovered in less than seven years' time.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong(In Mandarin): In view of the Minister's explanation, I beg leave to withdraw.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

Head 31 -

    Mr Ng Yeow Chong: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 31 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead101.

    Sir, this House was informed on 3rd December that the Hotel and Catering Training Centre would be extended to train more personnel in view of the expansion in the hotel trade in the Republic.

    Sir, you will agree that our hotel trade is now fast becoming an industry which earns quite sizable sums in foreign exchange for the Republic and also provides more opportunities for employment. In this respect, I have three questions to ask about the Hotel and Catering Training Centre:

    (1) What are the details of the expansion plans?

    (2) What are the built-in facilities mentioned by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour in his answer to my question for oral answer on 3rd December?

    (3) What are the necessary qualifications required for the various categories of trainees?

    The Chairman: The Question is,

    "That the sum to be allocated for Head 31 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 101."

    Mr Teong, would you like to speak now instead of moving your amendment* to the total sum, because under this head there is only one subhead?
* The amendment reads as follows:

    (2) That the total sum to be allocated for Head 31 be reduced by $100.


    Mr Teong Eng Siong(In Mandarin): I am not moving it.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour (Mr Sia Kah Hui): Mr Speaker, Sir, the expansion of the

Column: 706

training scheme for the hotel and catering industry involves the building of a hotel school with a view to increasing the scope of the training courses as well as increasing the intake of trainees. We have sought assistance from the Colombo Plan and the United Nations Development Programme Special Fund for experts. In fact, a hotel and catering adviser, whose services were obtained originally through the Asia Foundation and subsequently through the United Kingdom Government, has been here since June 1967. It is expected that another expert under the Colombo Plan, a waiting and bar services expert, will be here early next year.

    With regard to the building of a hotel school, there are at the moment three possible schemes under active study. The first scheme is to convert the present training centre into a two-storey building and the building facilities will include class-rooms, hotel bedrooms, a production kitchen, a training kitchen, a restaurant, a bar, a bakery, a hotel office, a language laboratory, a library, a communal room for trainees and staff, store-rooms and a swimming pool. The hotel bedrooms and the other public rooms are intended to be used for on-the-job training. A more ambitious scheme is to build a six-storey building with double the facilities of the first one. The third scheme is to convert a block of Government flats at Nassim Hill Road and, if possible, the con struction of another block nearby. But this will involve much more money than what has been provided. Anyway, these schemes are under active study and I think a decision will be arrived at shortly.

    As for the qualifications required for the various categories of trainees, I will just say that for waiters, barmen, waitresses, the minimum qualification will be Secondary II, the age between 16 and 22, and the training period will be about 12 weeks; for room stewards

Column: 707

or room stewardesses, a Secondary II or Vocational II qualification is required, the age between 20 and 25, and the training period will be six weeks; for the receptionist's course, a School Certificate is necessary, the age between 20 and 27, the male should have a minimum height of 5 feet 4 inches and the female 5 feet 2 inches, and the training period will be about five weeks. For the cashier's course, again a School Certificate is required, the age between 20 and 27 years, and the duration of training will be only one week.

3.00 p.m.

    Mr Yeoh Ghim Seng (Joo Chiat): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask the Parliamentary Secretary the reason for building a swimming pool at such a centre.

    Mr Ng Yeow Chong: I think $1.8 million is a big sum of money. We are extravagant in going to the extent of building a teaching hotel which is really unnecessary. We have numerous hotels in Singapore which can provide on-the-job training facilities.

    Mr Sim Boon Woo (Changi): I agree with the Member for Mountbatten.

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: Mr Speaker, Sir, the plan is only on paper. It is most likely that the swimming pool will not be built, and that the money will be more usefully spent on other projects. The intention is to give the trainees on-the-job training. In other words, it will be run just like an ordinary hotel. We can say that it is a teaching hotel. The trainees will get practical training. For the school a certain amount of income is possible.

    Mr Sia Khoon Seong (Moulmein): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Parliamentary Secretary, in reply to the Member for Joo Chiat, has raised a doubt whether the swimming pool will be built. I hope it will be built. I disagree with the Member for Joo Chiat and the Member for Mountbatten that the facilities in this teaching hotel are too extravagant. I think they are necessary

Column: 708

if we are to get good results from the training; that is, to produce good waiters and waitresses and other people dealing with hotel servicing. Unless the stu dents have the opportunity to train with facilities similar to those obtaining in the best hotels, I think they will need to be re-trained when they are actually employed as waiters and waitresses in hotels. I hope the swimming pool and all the other facilities envisaged in the plan will come through.

    Mr Ng Yeow Chong: I do not quite agree with the Member for Moulmein. Are we going to train the students in the swimming pool? Another point is that when we have overcome the shortage of hotel personnel, will the Government continue to run this hotel?

    The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Labour (Mr S. Rajaratnam): On a point of clarification. Before the Members go into deep waters, I must explain that the swimming pool is not for the trainees but for paying guests who will be actually using it so as to give realistic training to our hotel and catering staff.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong(In Mandarin): I wish to ask the Parliamentary Secretary why the trainees should have a certain height before they can be recruited as trainees.

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: Mr Speaker, Sir, that requirement applies only to receptionists. As the Member knows, receptionists should have certain qualities -among others, good looks as well as brains!

    An hon. Member: Is he qualified?

    Mr Ng Yeow Chong: I do not agree with the Parliamentary Secretary when he said just now that the expansion scheme is only on paper. In fact, the expansion plan must be pushed through as we all know very well that we will face a shortage of hotel employees by the end of 1971. By that time we will have about 30 hotels requiring something like 9,500 hotel employees. Unless we push through this plan urgently, we will not be able to overcome the

Column: 709

shortage of hotel employees. However, I beg leave to withdraw the amendment.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    The following amendment stood in the name of Mr Teong Eng Siong -

    (2) That the total sum to be allocated for Head 31 be reduced by $100.

    The Chairman: Amendment (2) . Mr Teong has indicated that he is not moving.

    The sum of $1,830,000 for Head 31 ordered to stand part of the Development Estimates.

Column: 709



    Head 41 -

    Mr Ho Kah Leong(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 41 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 203*.
* The same amendment also stood in the name of Mr Ch'ng Jit Koon.


    Mr Speaker, Sir, although I am moving a cut in the allocation, in my view the allocation is not enough. An increase should be made. As a graduate of Nanyang University, I have the responsibility of looking after its expansion. Twelve years have elapsed since the inception of Nantah in 1956. The number of graduates has already exceeded 3.700. At least 240 Nanyang graduates have returned from abroad with higher degrees. Some of them have returned to Nanyang University to take up teaching posts. The Government announced the recognition of Nanyang University degrees sometime this year. Next year there will be honours degree courses in Nanyang University. All this is very encouraging. In other words, Nanyang University is up and coming. In a matter of time it will definitely be able to make a more significant contribution in the field of higher education. But, unfortunately, the allocation for next year is only $100,000. I wonder whether such a small allocation is enough for the expansion of Nanyang University. I hope the Minister for Education will be able to persuade the Finance Minister to

Column: 710

make a bigger allocation. It should be at least ten times as much as what is being given now, in order to meet the expansion needs of Nanyang University.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I have several questions to ask under this subhead. Firstly, it is understood that the Language Centre of Nanyang University was set up with Government funds. I want to know whether the present language laboratory has six-channel facilities as originally planned. If the answer is in the negative, will there be any plans for its improve ment? Secondly, I wish to know whether there is any training scheme for higher studies for graduate assistants to take over those departments in Nanyang University which are overwhelmingly staffed by oversea personnel; such as the Department of History and the Department of Government Administration. With such a training scheme as part of the development programme of Nanyang University, there will be a sufficient supply of highly qualified local staff to man the various departments.

    Thirdly, as a portion of the sum allocated for this subhead is intended for the purchase of library books, I wish to know whether the Minister is convinced that the present librarian of Nanyang University is able to maintain the balance of books concerning Chinese culture published in Nationalist China and the People's Republic of China.

    Mr Ch'ng Jit Koon(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I support the Member for Jurong. I wish the Government can give more allocation to Nantah. When I read the 1969-70 Development Estimates, I was quite surprised. In the allocation for Nanyang University for the coming financial year, there is only $100,000 for the purchase of equipment and library books. There is no allocation for the extension of buildings and the provision of other facilities. There is not even a token provision. Does this mean that Nantah has all the facilities and, as such, does not need any allocation for further development in fields other than scientific equipment and library books? In my opinion, there are

Column: 711

still many fields in which Nantah needs improvement and development. In the past, Nanyang University has depended mainly on contributions from the people. Its expenditure on development has been tuned to its financial resources. All development has been on an austerity basis.

    Nantah should be different now. In the light of our present national development, Nanyang University could play an important part in education because of the recognition of the fact that it is part and parcel of the educational institutions of our country, it has a great role to play in nation building. All the defects that are existing should be rectified as soon as possible. In a very short time, Nantah has been able to produce many eminent scholars. Some have gone abroad for higher studies and have returned with the most up-to-date knowledge. Some have returned to teach in Nanyang University itself. We should not allow the knowledge they have acquired to be wasted. We must always renew ourselves. As the Chinese saying goes, "One must be newer and newer 'day by day." These scholars should not just write articles on what they have learnt, but should be able to put into practice what they have learnt. In view of the present scientific development in the world, we should encourage them to move with the times by providing them with research facilities so that they can further advance their knowledge. We should not let them be stagnant in their scientific field. Unless we provide them with such facilities, our country will suffer a loss. There is not even an electronic computer in Nanyang University. We may concede the fact that not all research necessitates the purchase of equipment, as in some Arts subjects. However, equipment is essential in scientific research. This is how some Nantah scientific scholars feel the need to have at least a small computer.

    At the moment, the quarters, too, are limited. The number is not enough for the teachers and students. The Nanyang University authorities have made it compulsory for first-year students to stay in the quarters. As a result, 95

Column: 712

per cent of the students are staying in the quarters. Other facilities, too, are not adequate. Nanyang University is very far away from the city. The stu dents do not have ample opportunities to take part in cultural and recreational activities. We are trying to evolve a rugged society. Yet when we look around Nanyang University, we find that there is not even a standard playground for the students to exercise or relax themselves.

    The Minister for Education has told us in this House that Nanyang University will introduce an honours degree course in the coming academic year. The sum allocated is only $100,000. This is the final part of the $1 million Government allocation. Will this sum of money be enough for the introduction and development of honours degree courses?

    I understand from the press that the Vice-Chancellor of Nantah will be retiring. Some honours degree courses will be introduced as from the next academic year. As Nanyang University is entering a new phase, it is necessary to appoint a new Vice-Chancellor. I wish to know whether the Minister has been informed that the Nantah authorities have taken any steps to appoint a new Vice-Chancellor.

3.15 p.m.

    The Minister for Education (Mr Ong Pang Boon): Mr Speaker, Sir, sometime in the middle of this year, Nanyang University did submit four projects for Government's consideration. The projects were for the construction of additional student hostels and the provision of additional staff quarters. These two projects would cost about $3 million. The third project was for the construction of a sports complex. The fourth project was for the improvement of ventilation for the Great Hall. The sports complex was estimated to cost about $620,000 and the ventilation for the Great Hall would cost about $20,000.

    The proposal to construct additional staff quarters was not supported as

Column: 713

Government's policy is to encourage home ownership. It would be preferable to grant loans to the staff to purchase their own houses. As regards the con struction of student hostels, about 80 per cent of the students are already accommodated in the existing hostels. Compared with other universities, this percentage is very high indeed and, therefore, the need for this project is not that urgent.

    The projects for the construction of a sports complex and improvement of the Great Hall were still under consideration at the time when the Development Estimates were prepared. Since no decision has yet been finalised, no provision was made in the Develop ment Estimates as regards these two items.

    In view of the financial stringency, it is likely that in future only requests of high priority such as funds for improvement of laboratories for honours degree courses and for research will be supported. Some of the equipment for honours degree courses will be arriving very soon. Some of it was purchased out of the $1 million grant for scientific equipment and library made in 1966. However, if this equipment is found to be inadequate, Government is always quite prepared to consider further requests.

    When the language laboratory was first installed, it was equipped with six channels. Later it was modified to one channel because it was under-used. Should the need arise, the language laboratory can be restored to the full six channels without any difficulty.

    The Member for Jurong also mentioned further studies by local staff. The policy to encourage further over seas training for graduate assistants so as to further enhance the academic standard of Nanyang University is being actively pursued by the University. I was told that this year two graduate assistants from the Department of Government and Public Administration were sent to Canada for higher training

Column: 714
